facts.text: Prior to 15th July, 1964, two separate services existed in Punjab: Provincial Civil Medical Service (PCMS) Class I and II, and Public Health Service Class I and II, each with separate seniority and promotion channels.
Post of District Medical Officer of Health was in Class II of Public Health Service; post of Assistant Director Health Services was in Class I of Public Health Service.

Appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh were District Medical Officers of Health in Class II of Public Health Service until promotion with retrospective effect from 25th April, 1964; Dr. Jagjit Singh senior to appellant.

Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 were in Class II of PCMS until promoted to Class I PCMS by order dated 8th April, 1964 with immediate effect; order conveyed by 23rd April, 1964; assumed charge between 27th April and 11th May, 1964.
Other Class II PCMS officers promoted on 8th April, 1964 allotted to Haryana on bifurcation, no longer contestants.
Dr. Jagjit Singh on deputation with Defence Department; appellant appointed to work in post of Assistant Director Health Services on own pay scale from 25th April, 1964.

PCMS and Public Health Service integrated effective 15th July, 1964 into combined PCMS Class I and II cadres; District Medical Officers equated to PCMS Class II; Assistant/Deputy Directors to PCMS Class I.

Appellant represented for promotion to Assistant Director from 25th April, 1964; State Government granted it; to protect Dr. Jagjit Singh's seniority, promoted him in absentia to Assistant Director from 25th April, 1964, and appellant vice him.
Both Dr. Jagjit Singh and appellant thus Assistant Directors from 25th April, 1964, absorbed in PCMS Class I on integration.

State Government memorandum dated 25th October, 1965: inter se seniority of Deputy/Assistant Directors from Public Health on integration in PCMS-I determined by length of continuous service from date of appointment in group, subject to not disturbing parent seniority.
Director Health Services communicated principle to appellant on 27th October, 1964; appellant opted for integration in PCMS Class I.
State Government order dated 4th December, 1967: seniority of Respondents Nos. 3-19 reckoned from date of appointment order (8th April, 1964), irrespective of assuming charge.
Provisional joint seniority list published showing Respondents Nos. 3-19 senior to Dr. Jagjit Singh and appellant.
Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab Haryana High Court challenging seniority list; Single Judge allowed, directing revision giving appellant seniority over Respondents 3-19.
State and some Respondents appealed via Letters Patent Appeals Nos. 446/1969 and 433/1969; Division Bench allowed appeals, upheld seniority list dated 8th April, 1970.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant has been given his proper rank in the joint seniority list of PCMS Class I after integration on 15th July, 1964, particularly interpreting clause 2(ii) of memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 on continuous service from date of appointment, and validity of order dated 4th December, 1967.
Whether 'date of appointment' means date of order with immediate effect or date of assuming charge.

petitioner_arguments.text: Inter se seniority per clause 2(ii) memorandum 25th October, 1965 determined by length of continuous service from date of appointment; appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh's service from 25th April, 1964; Respondents 3-19's continuous service commenced only on assuming charge after 25th April, 1964.

respondent_arguments.text: Memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 applied only to Public Health Service officers integrating into PCMS Class I, not inter se with existing PCMS Class I officers; competent for State to fix seniority of Respondents 3-19 from date of appointment order 8th April, 1964 irrespective of assuming charge.
State competent to issue administrative instructions and later order dated 4th December, 1967 fixing assumed date for continuous service.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 2(ii) memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 laid down principle for inter se seniority of officers from both services in integrated PCMS Class I by length of continuous service from date of appointment in group, subject to not disturbing parent seniority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle applies to both integrating services for fair adjustment.

court_reasoning.text: State can issue administrative instructions on seniority; cannot arbitrarily depart without rational justification, else violates Art. 14 and 16.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order 4th December, 1967 not departure as it aligns with principle.

court_reasoning.text: 'Date of appointment' for order with 'immediate effect' is date of order (8th April, 1964), not assuming charge; continuous service reckoned from that date even if charge assumed later.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondents 3-19's service from 8th April, 1964, longer than appellants' from 25th April, 1964.

holdings.text: Joint seniority list giving seniority to Respondents Nos. 3-19 over appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh upheld; their continuous service in PCMS Class I reckoned from 8th April, 1964.
Order dated 4th December, 1967 not violative of Art. 14/16 as it follows clause 2(ii) principle.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: State can issue administrative instructions on conditions of service in absence of statutory rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sant Ram Sharma v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: State executive power to issue administrative instructions on recruitment/conditions of service.
Executive agency must adhere to its own standards to avoid arbitrariness under equality principle.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 226 for writ petition; Arts. 14/16 against arbitrary departure from seniority principle.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; provisional joint seniority list of PCMS Class I upheld, placing Respondents Nos. 3-19 senior to appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh based on continuous service from date of appointment order.

key_quotes.text: "The seniority of Deputy Directors and Assistant Directors on the cadre of the Public Health on integration in PCMS-1 should be determined with reference to the length of continuous service from the date of appointment in the group subject to the condition that the seniority of a person in parent seniority list will not be disturbed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key principle from memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 interpreted by court.

key_quotes.text: "Where the State Government departs from a principle of seniority laid down by it, albeit by administrative instructions, and the departure is without reason and arbitrary, it would directly infringe the guarantee of equality under articles 14 and 16."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains constitutional limits on altering administrative instructions.

key_quotes.text: Order dated 8th April, 1964 appointed with "immediate effect"; date of appointment is date of order, continuous service reckoned therefrom irrespective of assuming charge.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of holding on 'date of appointment'.
